DataElement.preferredName: Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis Adjacent Tissue Evidence Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to describe the kind of evidence present in adjacent tissue related to primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC).

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis Adjacent Tissue Evidence
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A chronic, autoimmune inflammatory liver disorder characterized by narrowing and scarring of the lumen of the bile ducts. It is often seen in patients with ulcerative colitis. Signs and symptoms include jaundice, fatigue, and malabsorption. It may lead to cirrhosis and liver failure._Next to or adjoining._An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function._Knowledge on which to base belief.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A chronic, autoimmune inflammatory liver disorder characterized by narrowing and scarring of the lumen of the bile ducts. It is often seen in patients with ulcerative colitis. Signs and symptoms include jaundice, fatigue, and malabsorption. It may lead to cirrhosis and liver failure.

Concepts.definition: A chronic, autoimmune inflammatory liver disorder characterized by narrowing and scarring of the lumen of the bile ducts. It is often seen in patients with ulcerative colitis. Signs and symptoms include jaundice, fatigue, and malabsorption. It may lead to cirrhosis and liver failure.

Property.preferredDefinition: Next to or adjoining.:An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.:Knowledge on which to base belief.

Concepts.definition: An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.
Knowledge on which to base belief.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.: Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.

Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding indicating the presence of fibrosis around an intrahepatic bile duct in the liver tissue.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding indicating the presence of fibrosis around an intrahepatic bile duct in the liver tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding indicating the presence of typical or atypical proliferation of biliary epithelial cells in the portal tracts of the liver.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding indicating the presence of typical or atypical proliferation of biliary epithelial cells in the portal tracts of the liver.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding indicating reduction in the numbers of interlobular and septal bile ducts in the liver tissue.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding indicating reduction in the numbers of interlobular and septal bile ducts in the liver tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

Concepts.definition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.
